TITLE: Initializing Flow Production Tracking API in Python
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to initialize the Flow Production Tracking API (Shotgun) using the `shotgun_api3` library with script-based authentication. It requires the server path, script name, and script key. The code also includes an example of printing the available properties and methods on the `sg` connection object for debugging.
SOURCE: https://github.com/shotgunsoftware/python-api/blob/master/docs/cookbook/examples/basic_sg_instance.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: Python
CODE:
```
import pprint # Useful for debugging

import shotgun_api3

SERVER_PATH = "https://my-site.shotgrid.autodesk.com"
SCRIPT_NAME = 'my_script'
SCRIPT_KEY = '27b65d7063f46b82e670fe807bd2b6f3fd1676c1'

sg = shotgun_api3.Shotgun(SERVER_PATH, SCRIPT_NAME, SCRIPT_KEY)

# Just for demo purposes, this will print out property and method names available on the
# sg connection object
pprint.pprint([symbol for symbol in sorted(dir(sg)) if not symbol.startswith('_')])
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Script-based Authentication in Shotgun API (Python)
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to authenticate with the Shotgun API using a script's name and API key. The script must be registered with Shotgrid and have a valid API key. This method is recommended for automated processes and provides a way to track actions performed by the script.
SOURCE: https://github.com/shotgunsoftware/python-api/blob/master/docs/authentication.rst#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
sg = shotgun_api3.Shotgun("https://my-site.shotgrid.autodesk.com",
                              script_name="compress",
                              api_key="0123456789abcdef0123456789abcdef0123456789abcdef0123456789abcdef")
```

TITLE: Creating a Version linked to a Shot and Task using Shotgun API (Python)
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet creates a new Version entity in Shotgun and links it to a Shot and a Task. It uses the `sg.create` method with a dictionary containing the Version's data, including the project ID, code, description, path to frames, status, and links to the Shot and Task entities. The `entity` and `sg_task` fields are used to establish the links.
SOURCE: https://github.com/shotgunsoftware/python-api/blob/master/docs/cookbook/examples/basic_create_version_link_shot.rst#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
data = { 'project': {'type': 'Project','id': 4},
             'code': '100_010_anim_v1',
             'description': 'first pass at opening shot with bunnies',
             'sg_path_to_frames': '/v1/gun/s100/010/frames/anim/100_010_animv1_jack.#.jpg',
             'sg_status_list': 'rev',
             'entity': {'type': 'Shot', 'id': shot['id']},
             'sg_task': {'type': 'Task', 'id': task['id']},
             'user': {'type': 'HumanUser', 'id': 165} }
    result = sg.create('Version', data)
```

TITLE: Create Shot Entity - Python
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to create a Shot entity using the Shotgun API's `create()` method. The `sg` object is assumed to be an instance of the `shotgun_api3.Shotgun` class, initialized with the correct server path, script name, and script key. The data dictionary, as defined previously, is passed to the `create()` method along with the entity type 'Shot'.
SOURCE: https://github.com/shotgunsoftware/python-api/blob/master/docs/cookbook/examples/basic_create_shot.rst#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
result = sg.create('Shot', data)
```

TITLE: Complete Shot Creation Example - Python
DESCRIPTION: A complete example demonstrating how to create a Shot entity in Flow Production Tracking (Shotgun) using the Shotgun API. It includes setting up the connection, defining the data structure for the Shot, calling the `create` method and printing the result.
SOURCE: https://github.com/shotgunsoftware/python-api/blob/master/docs/cookbook/examples/basic_create_shot.rst#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
#!/usr/bin/env python

# --------------------------------------
# Imports
# --------------------------------------
import shotgun_api3
from pprint import pprint # useful for debugging

# --------------------------------------
# Globals
# --------------------------------------
# make sure to change this to match your Flow Production Tracking server and auth credentials.
SERVER_PATH = "https://my-site.shotgrid.autodesk.com"
SCRIPT_NAME = 'my_script'
SCRIPT_KEY = '27b65d7063f46b82e670fe807bd2b6f3fd1676c1'

# --------------------------------------
# Main
# --------------------------------------
if __name__ == '__main__':

    sg = shotgun_api3.Shotgun(SERVER_PATH, SCRIPT_NAME, SCRIPT_KEY)

    # --------------------------------------
    # Create a Shot with data
    # --------------------------------------
    data = {
        'project': {"type":"Project","id": 4},
        'code': '100_010',
        'description': 'Open on a beautiful field with fuzzy bunnies',
        'sg_status_list': 'ip'
    }
    result = sg.create('Shot', data)
    pprint(result)
    print("The id of the {} is {}.".format(result['type'], result['id']))
```

TITLE: Creating Task Dependency in Shotgun with Python
DESCRIPTION: This code creates a dependency between two tasks in Shotgun, making the 'Layout' task an upstream task to the 'Anm' task. It uses sg.update() to modify the 'Anm' task, setting its 'upstream_tasks' field to include the 'Layout' task with a 'finish-to-start-next-day' dependency type.
SOURCE: https://github.com/shotgunsoftware/python-api/blob/master/docs/cookbook/tasks/task_dependencies.rst#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
# make 'Layout' an upstream Task to 'Anm'. (aka, make 'Anm' dependent on 'Layout') with finish-to-start-next-day dependency type
data = {
    'upstream_tasks':[{'type':'Task','id':556, 'dependency_type': 'finish-to-start-next-day'}]
}
result = sg.update('Task', 557, data)
```

TITLE: Deleting Shot Entity - Shotgun API (Python)
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to delete a Shot entity using the `sg.delete` method from the Shotgun API. It requires a Shotgun API instance (`sg`) initialized with your server path, script name, and script key. The first argument specifies the entity type ('Shot'), and the second argument is the ID of the entity to delete.  The return value is a boolean representing if the delete was successful.
SOURCE: https://github.com/shotgunsoftware/python-api/blob/master/docs/cookbook/examples/basic_delete_shot.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
result = sg.delete("Shot", 40435)
```

TITLE: Create Flow Production Tracking Revision (Python)
DESCRIPTION: This Python script uses the Shotgun API to create a Revision in Flow Production Tracking. It retrieves environment variables set by the post-commit hook, validates the author as a Flow Production Tracking HumanUser, and creates the Revision with associated metadata, including a link to the revision in Trac. Requires the shotgun_api3_preview library and relies on specific environment variables.
SOURCE: https://github.com/shotgunsoftware/python-api/blob/master/docs/cookbook/examples/svn_integration.rst#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
#!/usr/bin/env python
# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Imports
# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
import sys
from shotgun_api3_preview import Shotgun
import os

# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Globals - update all of these values to those of your studio
# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
SERVER_PATH = 'https ://my-site.shotgrid.autodesk.com' # or http:
SCRIPT_USER = 'script_name'
SCRIPT_KEY = '3333333333333333333333333333333333333333'
REVISIONS_PATH = 'https ://serveraddress/trac/changeset/' # or other web-based UI
PROJECT = {'type':'Project', 'id':27}

# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Main
# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
if __name__ == '__main__':

   sg = Shotgun(SERVER_PATH, SCRIPT_USER, SCRIPT_KEY)

   # Set Python variables from the environment objects
   revision_code = os.environ['REV']
   repository = os.environ['REPOS']
   description = os.environ['COMMENT']
   author = os.environ['AUTHOR']

   # Set the Trac path for this specific revision
   revision_url = REVISIONS_PATH + revision_code

   # Validate that author is a valid Flow Production Tracking HumanUser
   result = sg.find_one("HumanUser", [['login', 'is', author]])
   if result:
       # Create Revision
       url = {'content_type':'http_url', 'url':revision_url, 'name':'Trac'}
       parameters = {'project':PROJECT,
                       'code':str(revision_code),
                       'description':description,
                       'attachment':url,
                       'created_by':{"type":"HumanUser", "id":result['id']}
                       }
       revision = sg.create("Revision", parameters)
       print("created Revision #"+str(revision_code))

   # Send error message if valid HumanUser is not found
   else:
       print("Unable to find a valid Flow Production Tracking User with login: {}, Revision not created in Flow Production Tracking.".format(author))
```

TITLE: Complex Shotgun Find Query Example (Python)
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates a complex find query using the Shotgun API. It retrieves all 'Shot' entities where the 'sg_status_list' is 'ip' AND the 'assets' field is linked to either an Asset with an ID of 9 OR an Asset with an ID of 23. It utilizes a nested filter with the 'any' operator.  It assumes that a Shotgun object 'sg' is already initialized and connected.
SOURCE: https://github.com/shotgunsoftware/python-api/blob/master/docs/reference.rst#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
filters = [
    ["sg_status_list", "is", "ip"],
    {
        "filter_operator": "any",
        "filters": [
            ["assets", "is", {"type": "Asset", "id": 9}],
            ["assets", "is", {"type": "Asset", "id": 23}]
        ]
    }
]
result = sg.find("Shot", filters)
```

TITLE: Download Attachment Function Python
DESCRIPTION: The download_attachment_to_disk function downloads an attachment from Flow Production Tracking to a local file. It calls extract_attachment_id to get the attachment's ID, then uses sg.download_attachment to retrieve the file stream. It writes the stream to the specified destination file and logs the download.
SOURCE: https://github.com/shotgunsoftware/python-api/blob/master/docs/cookbook/examples/ami_version_packager.rst#_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
# ----------------------------------------------
# Download Movie to Disk
# ----------------------------------------------
def download_attachment_to_disk(attachment,destination_filename):
    attachment_id = extract_attachment_id(attachment)
    if type(attachment_id) != int:
        return None
    # download the attachment file from Flow Production Tracking and write it to local disk
    logger.info("Downloading Attachment #%s" % (attachment_id))
    stream = sg.download_attachment(attachment_id)
    try:
        file = open(destination_filename, 'w')
        file.write(stream)
        file.close()
        logger.info("Downloaded attachment %s" % (destination_filename))
        return True
    except e:
        raise ShotgunException("unable to write attachment to disk: %s"% e)
```

TITLE: Find Project
DESCRIPTION: Finds a project in Shotgun based on its name. This example uses the sg.find() method to search for a project named 'Big Buck Bunny'.
SOURCE: https://github.com/shotgunsoftware/python-api/blob/master/docs/cookbook/usage_tips.rst#_snippet_11

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
# Get the project
project_name = 'Big Buck Bunny'
sg_project = sg.find("Project", [['name', 'is', project_name]])
```

TITLE: ShotgunAction Class Definition in Python
DESCRIPTION: Defines the `ShotgunAction` class responsible for parsing the URL sent from an Action Menu Item, extracting parameters, and storing them as instance variables.  The constructor takes a URL as input, parses it to extract the protocol, action, and parameters, and initializes instance variables such as entity type, project details, column information, and user data. The class also includes methods for logging and converting IDs to a filter format.
SOURCE: https://github.com/shotgunsoftware/python-api/blob/master/docs/cookbook/examples/ami_handler.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
class ShotgunAction:
    def __init__(self, url):
        self.logger = self._init_log(logfile)
        self.url = url
        self.protocol, self.action, self.params = self._parse_url()

        # entity type that the page was displaying
        self.entity_type = self.params["entity_type"]

        # Project info (if the ActionMenuItem was launched from a page not belonging
        # to a Project (Global Page, My Page, etc.), this will be blank
        if "project_id" in self.params:
            self.project = {
                "id": int(self.params["project_id"]),
                "name": self.params["project_name"],
            }
        else:
            self.project = None

        # Internal column names currently displayed on the page
        self.columns = self.params["cols"]

        # Human readable names of the columns currently displayed on the page
        self.column_display_names = self.params["column_display_names"]

        # All ids of the entities returned by the query (not just those visible on the page)
        self.ids = []
        if len(self.params["ids"]) > 0:
            ids = self.params["ids"].split(",")
            self.ids = [int(id) for id in ids]

        # All ids of the entities returned by the query in filter format ready
        # to use in a find() query
        self.ids_filter = self._convert_ids_to_filter(self.ids)

        # ids of entities that were currently selected
        self.selected_ids = []
        if len(self.params["selected_ids"]) > 0:
            sids = self.params["selected_ids"].split(",")
            self.selected_ids = [int(id) for id in sids]

        # All selected ids of the entities returned by the query in filter format ready
        # to use in a find() query
        self.selected_ids_filter = self._convert_ids_to_filter(self.selected_ids)

        # sort values for the page
        # (we don't allow no sort anymore, but not sure if there's legacy here)
        if "sort_column" in self.params:
            self.sort = {
                "column": self.params["sort_column"],
                "direction": self.params["sort_direction"],
            }
        else:
            self.sort = None

        # title of the page
        self.title = self.params["title"]

        # user info who launched the ActionMenuItem
        self.user = {"id": self.params["user_id"], "login": self.params["user_login"]}

        # session_uuid
        self.session_uuid = self.params["session_uuid"]
```

TITLE: Filtering Version by Name and Latest Entity Created (Python)
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to use additional filter presets to find the Version with a specific name that is linked to the latest entity created. It combines a standard filter for the 'code' field with an 'additional_filter_presets' parameter to achieve this.  The Shotgun API `sg.find` method is called to execute the query.
SOURCE: https://github.com/shotgunsoftware/python-api/blob/master/docs/reference.rst#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
additional_filter_presets = [
    {
        "preset_name": "LATEST",
        "latest_by":   "ENTITIES_CREATED_AT"
    }
]

filters = [['code', 'is', 'ABC']]

result = sg.find('Version', filters = filters, additional_filter_presets = additional_filter_presets)
```

TITLE: Finding Custom Entities
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to use the custom entity global variables to query the Shotgun database for entities of a specific custom type. It utilizes the `shotgun_api3` library and the `studio_globals` module defined in prior snippets to make a query.
SOURCE: https://github.com/shotgunsoftware/python-api/blob/master/docs/cookbook/usage_tips.rst#_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
import shotgun_api3
import studio_globals

sg = shotgun_api3.Shotgun('https://my-site.shotgrid.autodesk.com', 'script_name', '0123456789abcdef0123456789abcdef0123456')
result = sg.find(studio_globals.ENTITY_WIDGET,
                 filters=[['sg_status_list', 'is', 'ip']],
                 fields=['code', 'sg_shot'])
```

TITLE: Finding Playlist Version Connections
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to find `PlaylistVersionConnection` entities to retrieve information about Versions within a specific Playlist, including their sort order and associated data. It uses dot notation to access fields from linked entities.
SOURCE: https://github.com/shotgunsoftware/python-api/blob/master/docs/cookbook/usage_tips.rst#_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
filters = [['playlist', 'is', {'type':'Playlist', 'id':4}]]
fields = ['playlist.Playlist.code', 'sg_sort_order', 'version.Version.code', 'version.Version.user', 'version.Version.entity']
order=[{'column':'sg_sort_order','direction':'asc'}]
result = sg.find('PlaylistVersionConnection', filters, fields, order)
```

TITLE: Querying Tasks with Dependency Fields in Shotgun Python API
DESCRIPTION: This snippet queries for Tasks associated with a specific Shot in Shotgun using the sg.find() method, retrieving specified fields including dependency-related fields like 'upstream_tasks' and 'downstream_tasks'. It filters the tasks based on the 'entity' field (Shot).
SOURCE: https://github.com/shotgunsoftware/python-api/blob/master/docs/cookbook/tasks/task_dependencies.rst#_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
filters = [
    ['entity', 'is', {'type':'Shot', 'id':860}]
]
fields = [
    'content',
    'start_date',
    'due_date',
    'upstream_tasks',
    'downstream_tasks',
    'dependency_violation',
    'pinned'
    ]
result = sg.find("Task", filters, fields)
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Resolving Dependency Violation in Shotgun with Python
DESCRIPTION: This snippet resolves a dependency violation by updating the 'start_date' of a Task to a valid date after the end date of its upstream task. It uses sg.update() to modify the 'start_date' for the Task with ID 557 to '2010-05-10'.
SOURCE: https://github.com/shotgunsoftware/python-api/blob/master/docs/cookbook/tasks/task_dependencies.rst#_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
result = sg.update('Task', 557, {'start_date': '2010-05-10'})
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Attachment ID Extraction Python
DESCRIPTION: The extract_attachment_id function extracts the Attachment ID from the URL within an attachment dictionary. It splits the URL string and attempts to convert the last part to an integer. Returns None if not an integer.
SOURCE: https://github.com/shotgunsoftware/python-api/blob/master/docs/cookbook/examples/ami_version_packager.rst#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
# ----------------------------------------------
# Extract Attachment id from entity field
# ----------------------------------------------
def extract_attachment_id(attachment):
    # extract the Attachment id from the url location
    attachment_id = attachment['url'].rsplit('/',1)[1]
    try:
        attachment_id = int(attachment_id)
    except:
        # not an integer.
        return None
        # raise ShotgunException("invalid Attachment id returned. Expected an integer: %s "% attachment_id)

    return attachment_id
```

TITLE: Find Task Template by Code - Python
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates how to find a Task Template in Flow Production Tracking by its code using the `sg.find_one` method. It requires the `sg` object, which is assumed to be an initialized Shotgun API instance. The snippet filters Task Templates based on the 'code' field.
SOURCE: https://github.com/shotgunsoftware/python-api/blob/master/docs/cookbook/examples/basic_create_shot_task_template.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
filters = [['code','is', '3D Shot Template' ]]
template = sg.find_one('TaskTemplate', filters)
```

TITLE: Finding Versions Associated with a Cut via CutItems (Python)
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet shows how to find all Version entities associated with the Shot linked to the CutItems of a specific Cut. It uses the `CUT_SHOT_VERSIONS` filter preset, passing the Cut's ID as a parameter. The Shotgun API `sg.find` method is called to execute the query, filtering versions using the specified filter presets.
SOURCE: https://github.com/shotgunsoftware/python-api/blob/master/docs/reference.rst#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
additional_filter_presets = [
    {
        "preset_name": "CUT_SHOT_VERSIONS",
        "cut_id":       1
    }
]

result = sg.find('Version', additional_filter_presets = additional_filter_presets)
```

TITLE: Updating Task: Ignoring Start/Due Dates & Duration Python
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet shows how the Shotgun API ignores 'start_date', 'due_date', and 'duration' when updating a Task's 'splits' field. The 'start_date', 'due_date', and 'duration' values are overridden by the split definitions.
SOURCE: https://github.com/shotgunsoftware/python-api/blob/master/docs/cookbook/tasks/split_tasks.rst#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
sg.update('Task', 2088, {
        'start_date': '2012-12-06',
        'due_date': '2012-12-23',
        'duration': 3600,
        'splits': [
            {'start': '2012-12-11', 'end': '2012-12-12'},
            {'start': '2012-12-18', 'end': '2012-12-19'}
        ]
    })
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Disabling SSL Certificate Validation in Shotgun API (Python)
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet shows how to disable SSL certificate validation in the Shotgun Python API to work around SSL errors like "unknown field: SERIALNUMBER=0123456789" or ":SSL3_GET_SERVER_CERTIFICATE:certificate verify failed". Setting the NO_SSL_VALIDATION constant to True disables the validation.
SOURCE: https://github.com/shotgunsoftware/python-api/blob/master/docs/advanced/iron_python.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
NO_SSL_VALIDATION = True
```

TITLE: Unsetting a Local File Field Value (Python)
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to unset a local file field value (e.g., sg_uploaded_movie) by setting its value to None using the Shotgun Python API. This effectively removes the associated local file link from the Shotgun entity. Requires the Shotgun Python API.
SOURCE: https://github.com/shotgunsoftware/python-api/blob/master/docs/cookbook/attachments.rst#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
data = {'sg_uploaded_movie': None}
    result = sg.update('Version', 123, data)
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Subversion Post-Commit Hook Script (Shell)
DESCRIPTION: This shell script serves as a post-commit hook for Subversion. It captures the repository path, revision number, author, and commit message, and then invokes a Python script (shotgun_api_script.py) to create the Revision in Flow Production Tracking. It relies on the svnlook command to extract information from the Subversion repository.
SOURCE: https://github.com/shotgunsoftware/python-api/blob/master/docs/cookbook/examples/svn_integration.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: sh
CODE:
```
#!/bin/sh
# POST-COMMIT HOOK

REPOS="$1"
REV="$2"

export AUTHOR="$(svnlook author $REPOS --revision $REV)"
export COMMENT="$(svnlook log $REPOS --revision $REV)"

/Absolute/path/to/shotgun_api_script.py
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Complete Example - Deleting Shot with Shotgun API (Python)
DESCRIPTION: This is a complete example demonstrating how to connect to ShotGrid using the `shotgun_api3` library and delete a Shot entity.  It initializes a Shotgun API instance (`sg`) with the server path, script name, and script key, then calls the `sg.delete` method to delete a Shot with the ID 40435.  It requires the `shotgun_api3` library to be installed and the `SERVER_PATH`, `SCRIPT_NAME`, and `SCRIPT_KEY` variables to be set correctly for your ShotGrid instance.
SOURCE: https://github.com/shotgunsoftware/python-api/blob/master/docs/cookbook/examples/basic_delete_shot.rst#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
#!/usr/bin/env python

# --------------------------------------
# Imports
# --------------------------------------
import shotgun_api3
from pprint import pprint # useful for debugging

# --------------------------------------
# Globals
# --------------------------------------
# make sure to change this to match your Flow Production Tracking server and auth credentials.
SERVER_PATH = "https://my-site.shotgrid.autodesk.com"
SCRIPT_NAME = 'my_script'
SCRIPT_KEY = '27b65d7063f46b82e670fe807bd2b6f3fd1676c1'

# --------------------------------------
# Main
# --------------------------------------
if __name__ == '__main__':

    sg = shotgun_api3.Shotgun(SERVER_PATH, SCRIPT_NAME, SCRIPT_KEY)

    # --------------------------------------
    # Delete a Shot by id
    # --------------------------------------
    result = sg.delete("Shot", 40435)
    pprint(result)
```

TITLE: ActionMenuItem Script Setup Python
DESCRIPTION: This code initializes the script to be run from an ActionMenuItem in Flow Production Tracking. It imports necessary modules, defines the ShotgunAction class (presumably from an external file), and sets up basic variables for Shotgun connection and file handling. The script parses POST variables from the ActionMenuItem.
SOURCE: https://github.com/shotgunsoftware/python-api/blob/master/docs/cookbook/examples/ami_version_packager.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
#!/usr/bin/env python
# encoding: utf-8
"""
version_packager.py

This example script is meant to be run from an ActionMenuItem in Flow Production Tracking. The menu item uses a custom
protocol in order to launch this script, and is followed by the action 'package4client'. So the full
url would be something like launchme://package4client?.... See:
https://developer.shotgridsoftware.com/python-api/cookbook/examples/ami_handler.html

It uses the example ActionMenu Python class also located in our docs for parsing the ActionMenuItem
POST variables. For more information about it and accessing the variables in the ActionMenuItem POST request,
See: http://developer.shotgridsoftware.com/python-api/examples/ami_handler

The purpose of this script is to download attachment files from Flow Production Tracking, create an archive of them
and copy them to a specified directory. You can invoke it with the following minimal example to connect
to Flow Production Tracking, download any file that exists in the specified field ('sg_qt') for each selected_id passed from the
ActionMenu. Then it will create a single archive of the files and move it to the specified directory
('/path/where/i/want/to/put/the/archive/'). The archive is named with the Project Name, timestamp, and user
login who ran the ActionMenuItem ('Demo_Project_2010-04-29-172210_kp.tar.gz'):

    sa = ShotgunAction(sys.argv[1])
    sg = shotgun_connect()
    if sa.action == 'package4client':
        r = packageFilesForClient('sg_qt','/path/where/i/want/to/put/the/archive/')

"""

# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Imports
# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
import sys, os
import logging as logger
import subprocess
import re
from datetime import datetime

from shotgun_api3 import Shotgun
from shotgun_action import ShotgunAction
from pprint import pprint

# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Variables
# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Flow Production Tracking server auth info
shotgun_conf = {
    'url':'https://my-site.shotgrid.autodesk.com',
    'name':'YOUR_SCRIPT_NAME_HERE',
    'key':'YOUR_SCRIPT_KEY_HERE'
    }

# location to write logfile for this script
logfile = os.path.dirname(sys.argv[0])+"/version_packager.log"

# temporary directory to download movie files to and create thumbnail files in
file_dir = os.path.dirname(sys.argv[0])+"/tmp"

# compress command
# tar czf /home/user/backup_www.tar.gz -C / var/www/html
compress_cmd = "tar czf %s -C / %s"
```

TITLE: URL Parsing in Python
DESCRIPTION: The `_parse_url` method is responsible for parsing the URL received from the Action Menu Item. It extracts the protocol, action, and parameters from the URL string. The parameters are then further processed to handle cases where certain keys, such as 'column_display_names' and 'cols', may appear multiple times in the URL.
SOURCE: https://github.com/shotgunsoftware/python-api/blob/master/docs/cookbook/examples/ami_handler.rst#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
def _parse_url(self):
    logger.info("Parsing full url received: %s" % self.url)

    # get the protocol used
    protocol, path = self.url.split(":", 1)
    logger.info("protocol: %s" % protocol)

    # extract the action
    action, params = path.split("?", 1)
    action = action.strip("/")
    logger.info("action: %s" % action)

    # extract the parameters
    # 'column_display_names' and 'cols' occurs once for each column displayed so we store it as a list
    params = params.split("&")
    p = {"column_display_names": [], "cols": []}
    for arg in params:
        key, value = map(six.moves.urllib.parse.unquote, arg.split("=", 1))
        if key == "column_display_names" or key == "cols":
            p[key].append(value)
        else:
            p[key] = value
    params = p
    logger.info("params: %s" % params)
    return (protocol, action, params)
```

TITLE: File Compression Function Python
DESCRIPTION: The compress_files function compresses a list of files into a tar.gz archive. It constructs a shell command using 'tar czf', executes the command using subprocess.Popen, and logs the output. It expects a list of file paths and a destination filename.
SOURCE: https://github.com/shotgunsoftware/python-api/blob/master/docs/cookbook/examples/ami_version_packager.rst#_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
# ----------------------------------------------
# Compress files
# ----------------------------------------------
def compress_files(files,destination_filename):
    destination_filename += ".tar.gz"
    files = [path.lstrip("/") for path in files]
    squish_me = compress_cmd % (destination_filename, " ".join(files) )
    logger.info("Compressing %s files..." % len(files))
    logger.info("Running command: %s" % squish_me)
    try:
        output = subprocess.Popen(squish_me, shell=True, stdout=subprocess.PIPE).stdout.read()
        logger.info('tar/gzip command returned: %s' % output)
    except e:
        raise ShotgunException("unable compress files: %s"% e)
    logger.info("compressed files to: %s" % destination_filename)
    return destination_filename
```

TITLE: Logging Initialization in Python
DESCRIPTION: The `_init_log` method configures the logging for the `ShotgunAction` class. It sets the log level to DEBUG, defines the log message format, and specifies the filename and mode for the log file. It handles potential `IOError` exceptions that may occur when attempting to open the log file for writing.
SOURCE: https://github.com/shotgunsoftware/python-api/blob/master/docs/cookbook/examples/ami_handler.rst#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
def _init_log(self, filename="shotgun_action.log"):
    try:
        logger.basicConfig(
            level=logger.DEBUG,
            format="%(asctime)s %(levelname)-8s %(message)s",
            datefmt="%Y-%b-%d %H:%M:%S",
            filename=filename,
            filemode="w+",
        )
    except IOError as e:
        raise ShotgunActionException("Unable to open logfile for writing: %s" % e)
    logger.info("ShotgunAction logging started.")
    return logger
```

TITLE: Logging Setup Function Python
DESCRIPTION: The init_log function initializes the logging system. It sets the logging level to DEBUG, defines the log format, and specifies the filename for the log file. It handles potential IOError exceptions when opening the log file for writing and raises a ShotgunException if an error occurs.
SOURCE: https://github.com/shotgunsoftware/python-api/blob/master/docs/cookbook/examples/ami_version_packager.rst#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
# ----------------------------------------------
# Set up logging
# ----------------------------------------------
def init_log(filename="version_packager.log"):
    try:
        logger.basicConfig(level=logger.DEBUG,
                        format='%(asctime)s %(levelname)-8s %(message)s',
                        datefmt='%Y-%b-%d %H:%M:%s',
                        filename=filename,
                        filemode='w+')
    except IOError, e:
        raise ShotgunException ("Unable to open logfile for writing: %s" % e)
    logger.info("Version Packager logging started.")
    return logger
```

TITLE: ID Conversion to Filter in Python
DESCRIPTION: The `_convert_ids_to_filter` method converts a list of IDs into a filter format that can be used in Shotgun find() queries. It iterates through the input list of IDs and constructs a filter array, where each element is a list containing the 'id', 'is', and the ID value.
SOURCE: https://github.com/shotgunsoftware/python-api/blob/master/docs/cookbook/examples/ami_handler.rst#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
def _convert_ids_to_filter(self, ids):
    filter = []
    for id in ids:
        filter.append(["id", "is", id])
    logger.debug("parsed ids into: %s" % filter)
    return filter
```

TITLE: Remove Downloaded Files Function Python
DESCRIPTION: The remove_downloaded_files function removes a list of files from the file system. It constructs a shell command using 'rm', executes the command using subprocess.Popen, and logs the output. It expects a list of file paths.
SOURCE: https://github.com/shotgunsoftware/python-api/blob/master/docs/cookbook/examples/ami_version_packager.rst#_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
# ----------------------------------------------
# Remove downloaded files
# ----------------------------------------------
def remove_downloaded_files(files):
    remove_me = 'rm %s' % ( " ".join(files) )
    logger.info("Removing %s files..." % len(files))
    logger.info("Running command: %s" % remove_me)
    try:
        output = subprocess.Popen(remove_me, shell=True, stdout=subprocess.PIPE).stdout.read()
        logger.info('rm command returned: %s' % output)
        logger.info("removed downloaded files")
        return True
    except e:
        logger.error("unable remove files: %s"% e)
        return False
```

TITLE: File Copy Function Python
DESCRIPTION: The copy_files function copies files to a destination directory using the 'mv' command. It constructs the shell command and executes it using subprocess.Popen. It handles potential OSError exceptions during the copy operation. It handles the cases for copying single files or multiple files.
SOURCE: https://github.com/shotgunsoftware/python-api/blob/master/docs/cookbook/examples/ami_version_packager.rst#_snippet_7

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
# ----------------------------------------------
# Copy files
# ----------------------------------------------
def copy_files(files,destination_directory):
    if type(files) == list:
        files = " ".join(files)
    copy_me_args = "%s %s" % (files, destination_directory)
    logger.info("Running command: mv %s" % copy_me_args)
    try:
        result = subprocess.Popen("mv " + copy_me_args, shell=True, stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.PIPE)
        # 0 = success, 1 = recoverable issues
        if result.returncode > 0:
            response = result.stderr.read()
            logger.error("Copy failed: %s"% response)
            raise ShotgunException("Copy failed: %s"% response)
    except OSError, e:
        raise ShotgunException("unable copy files: %s"% e)

    logger.info("copied files to: %s" % destination_directory)
    return destination_directory
```

TITLE: Package Files for Client Function Python
DESCRIPTION: The packageFilesForClient function orchestrates the entire packaging process. It queries Shotgun for entities based on selected IDs, downloads attachments, compresses them into an archive, removes the original downloaded files, and copies the archive to the destination directory.  The function requires the file_field and destination_dir parameters.
SOURCE: https://github.com/shotgunsoftware/python-api/blob/master/docs/cookbook/examples/ami_version_packager.rst#_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
def packageFilesForClient(file_field,destination_dir):

    # get entities matching the selected ids
    logger.info("Querying Shotgun for %s %ss" % (len(sa.selected_ids_filter), sa.params['entity_type']))
    entities = sg.find(sa.params['entity_type'],sa.selected_ids_filter,['id','code',file_field],filter_operator='any')

    # download the attachments for each entity, zip them, and copy to destination directory
    files = []
    for e in entities:
        if not e[file_field]:
            logger.info("%s #%s: No file exists. Skippinsa." % (sa.params['entity_type'], e['id']))
        else:
            logger.info("%s #%s: %s" % (sa.params['entity_type'], e['id'], e[file_field]))
            path_to_file = file_dir+"/"+re.sub(r"\s+", '_', e[file_field]['name'])
            result = download_attachment_to_disk(e[file_field], path_to_file )

        # only include attachments. urls won't return true
        if result:
            files.append(path_to_file)

    # compress files
    # create a nice valid destination filename
    project_name = ''
    if 'project_name' in sa.params:
        project_name = re.sub(r"\s+", '_', sa.params['project_name'])+'_'
    dest_filename = project_name+datetime.today().strftime('%Y-%m-%d-%H%M%S')+"_"+sa.params['user_login']
    archive = compress_files(files,file_dir+"/"+dest_filename)

    # now that we have the archive, remove the downloads
    r = remove_downloaded_files(files)

    # copy to directory
    result = copy_files([archive],destination_dir)

    return True
```

TITLE: Complete Shotgun Update Example Python
DESCRIPTION: This complete example demonstrates how to authenticate with the Shotgun API, connect to a Shotgun server, and update a Shot entity with new data. It includes importing the necessary libraries, setting up authentication credentials, creating a Shotgun API instance, defining the update data, calling the `update` method, and printing the result. Requires shotgun_api3 and pprint.
SOURCE: https://github.com/shotgunsoftware/python-api/blob/master/docs/cookbook/examples/basic_update_shot.rst#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
#!/usr/bin/env python

# --------------------------------------
# Imports
# --------------------------------------
import shotgun_api3
from pprint import pprint # useful for debugging

# --------------------------------------
# Globals
# --------------------------------------
# make sure to change this to match your Flow Production Tracking server and auth credentials.
SERVER_PATH = "https://my-site.shotgrid.autodesk.com"
SCRIPT_NAME = 'my_script'
SCRIPT_KEY = '27b65d7063f46b82e670fe807bd2b6f3fd1676c1'

# --------------------------------------
# Main
# --------------------------------------
if __name__ == '__main__':

    sg = shotgun_api3.Shotgun(SERVER_PATH, SCRIPT_NAME, SCRIPT_KEY)

    # --------------------------------------
    # Update Shot with data
    # --------------------------------------
    data = {
        'description': 'Open on a beautiful field with fuzzy bunnies',
        'sg_status_list': 'ip'
        }
    result = sg.update('Shot', 40435, data)
    pprint(result)
```

TITLE: Finding a Task using Shotgun API (Python)
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet finds a Task entity in Shotgun that is related to a specific Shot and has a specific content name. It uses the `sg.find_one` method with filters that include the project ID, the Shot's ID (obtained from the previous snippet), and the task's content. The returned `task` variable contains the Task's data, including its ID, which is necessary for linking it to a Version.
SOURCE: https://github.com/shotgunsoftware/python-api/blob/master/docs/cookbook/examples/basic_create_version_link_shot.rst#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
filters = [ ['project', 'is', {'type': 'Project', 'id': 4}],
                ['entity', 'is',{'type':'Shot', 'id': shot['id']}],
                ['content', 'is', 'Animation'] ]
    task = sg.find_one('Task', filters)
```
